ratings.comment: Physics 241 with Dr. Joynt was a good class. There were weekly homework assignments, recommended textbooks readings (he followed the textbook closely), and pretty generous grading on exams. Tests are worth a lot, but are 3 problems and only your best 2 are graded. Very manageable class, helpful to read the textbook, posts nice lecture notes.
He is a great guy, a very nice person. Lectures are fun but you will need to read the textbook and do practice questions to understand physics. Best professor so far.

He is a really nice guy, but not an amazing instructor. The lectures can be disorganized and confusing sometimes, and he has a tendency to over-emphasize things that don't matter that much while glossing over the important stuff. Pop-quizzes!! The tests are terrifying because they are only 3 questions each and he grades the best 2.

Weekly homework was always tough and nothing was gone over in the discussion so that was pointless. Exams were 10 questions multiple choice but were super difficult questions and seemed like some material wasn't even touched on. Lectures are monotonous and confusing.

Not a good intro level physics course. He expected you to have a good understanding already and didn't explain the simple things easily. Homework every week and super short tests which counted for a lot of your grade. Discussions weren't mandatory and didn't go in depth into any of the info covered in class.

You can tell he prefers to teach the higher level classes, and had a difficult time keeping the students engaged throughout the class hour. By the end of the semester, only a third of the class was still showing up, and only a third of those paid attention. The topics were interesting at times, but his monotone, nasally speech patterns made it hard
Overall a nice guy with a decent lecture style. His teaching is old school and assumes students understand the concepts coming into the class.

Like others said, Bob is a nice guy. I just wish I could say the same about his lectures. They are very unclear, especially for those who have never had physics experience before. He does not do a good job explaining the concepts used in class. He fails the most important thing needed in a physics course: the ability to make the student understand.

Dr. Joynt is a super nice guy but he is very, very unclear in his lectures. The homework he assigns doesn't relate to what he teaches in class making it a huge pain to try to figure out how to do it. His class is relatively easy but the lectures are boring and feel irrelevant.

Hated this class. Prof gives general overview of topics in this class, but neither he nor the book give any indication of how to do the problems for homework and exams. I went in for help, all he said was "draw pics". Sometimes section was helpful, but overall it was incredibly frustrating to be tested on material I had to teach myself or google.

Prof Joynt is a nice guy but his lectures are hard to comprehend. You would want to read the textbook (an interesting one) and search for extra resources outside the class. He's willing to help, so if you have any questions just go ahead and clarify with him. Also, there's an essay to turn in near the end of sem. Workload is manageable.

The class is called physics for non-physics majors, but still requires you to think like a physicist. Lectures give an overview but no help understanding how to do the homework/exams. Even discussions are nothing more than problems being thrown at you without any examples or explanation. I've never been more confused,frustrated, or lost in a class.
